member.summary: Optional factory for implementations. If is set this property will be ignored.

member.name: P:PuppeteerSharp.ConnectOptions.EnqueueTransportMessages
member.summary: If not is set this will be use to determine is the default will enqueue messages.
member.remarks: It's set to true by default because it's the safest way to send commands to Chromium. Setting this to false proved to work in .NET Core but it tends to fail on .NET Framework.

member.name: P:PuppeteerSharp.ConnectOptions.EnqueueAsyncMessages
member.summary: Affects how responses to are returned to the caller. If true (default), the response is delivered to the caller on its own thread; otherwise, the response is delivered the same way events are raised.
member.remarks: This should normally be set to true to support applications that aren't async "all the way up"; i.e., the application has legacy code that is not async which makes calls into PuppeteerSharp. If you experience issues, or your application is not mixed sync/async use, you can set this to false (default).

member.name: M:PuppeteerSharp.ElementHandle.SelectAsync(System.String[])
member.summary: Triggers a `change` and `input` event once all the provided options have been selected. If there's no `select` element matching `selector`, the method throws an exception.

example.code: await handle.SelectAsync("blue"); // single selection await handle.SelectAsync("red", "green", "blue"); // multiple selections

member.param: Values of options to select. If the `select` has the `multiple` attribute, all values are considered, otherwise only the first one is taken into account.
member.returns: A task that resolves to an array of option values that have been successfully selected.

member.name: T:PuppeteerSharp.Frame
member.summary:
Provides methods to interact with a single page frame in Chromium. One instance might have multiple instances. At every point of time, page exposes its current frame tree via the and properties.
object's lifecycle is controlled by three events, dispatched on the page object - - fires when the frame gets attached to the page. A Frame can be attached to the page only once - - fired when the frame commits navigation to a different URL - - fired when the frame gets detached from the page. A Frame can be detached from the page only once

member.name: M:PuppeteerSharp.Frame.GoToAsync(System.String,PuppeteerSharp.NavigationOptions)
member.remarks:
will throw an error if: - there's an SSL error (e.g. in case of self-signed certificates). - target URL is invalid. - the `timeout` is exceeded during navigation. - the remote server does not respond or is unreachable. - the main resource failed to load.
will not throw an error when any valid HTTP status code is returned by the remote server, including 404 "Not Found" and 500 "Internal Server Error". The status code for such responses can be retrieved by calling
> **NOTE** either throws an error or returns a main resource response. The only exceptions are navigation to `about:blank` or navigation to the same URL with a different hash, which would succeed and return `null`.
> **NOTE** Headless mode doesn't support navigation to a PDF document. See the upstream issue.
member.param: URL to navigate page to. The url should include scheme, e.g. https://.
member.returns: Task which resolves to the main resource response. In case of multiple redirects, the navigation will resolve with the response of the last redirect.

member.name: M:PuppeteerSharp.Frame.GoToAsync(System.String,System.Nullable{System.Int32},PuppeteerSharp.WaitUntilNavigation[])
member.param: URL to navigate page to. The url should include scheme, e.g. https://.
maximum navigation time in milliseconds. Defaults to 30 seconds. Pass 0 to disable timeout. The default value can be changed by using the property.
When to consider navigation succeeded, defaults to . Given an array of , navigation is considered to be successful after all events have been fired
member.returns: Task which resolves to the main resource response. In case of multiple redirects, the navigation will resolve with the response of the last redirect

member.name: M:PuppeteerSharp.Frame.WaitForNavigationAsync(PuppeteerSharp.NavigationOptions)
member.summary: This resolves when the frame navigates to a new URL or reloads. It is useful for when you run code which will indirectly cause the frame to navigate.
member.returns: Task which resolves to the main resource response. In case of multiple redirects, the navigation will resolve with the response of the last redirect. In case of navigation to a different anchor or navigation due to History API usage, the navigation will resolve with `null`.
member.remarks: Usage of the History API to change the URL is considered a navigation

member.summary: If not is set this will be use to determine is the default will enqueue messages.

member.name: P:PuppeteerSharp.LaunchOptions.Product
member.summary: The browser to be used (Chrome, Firefox)

member.name: P:PuppeteerSharp.LaunchOptions.EnqueueAsyncMessages
member.summary: Affects how responses to are returned to the caller. If true (default), the response is delivered to the caller on its own thread; otherwise, the response is delivered the same way events are raised.
member.remarks: This should normally be set to true to support applications that aren't async "all the way up"; i.e., the application has legacy code that is not async which makes calls into PuppeteerSharp. If you experience issues, or your application is not mixed sync/async use, you can set this to false (default).

member.name: M:PuppeteerSharp.Page.EvaluateOnNewDocumentAsync(System.String,System.Object[])
member.summary: Adds a function which would be invoked in one of the following scenarios: - whenever the page is navigated - whenever the child frame is attached or navigated. In this case, the function is invoked in the context of the newly attached frame
member.param: Function to be evaluated in browser context
member.remarks: The function is invoked after the document was created but before any of its scripts were run. This is useful to amend JavaScript environment, e.g. to seed Math.random.
member.example:
An example of overriding the navigator.languages property before the page loads:
await page.EvaluateOnNewDocumentAsync("() => window.__example = true");
member.returns: Task

await page.EvaluateFunctionOnNewDocumentAsync("() => window.__example = true");

member.remarks:
will throw an error if: - there's an SSL error (e.g. in case of self-signed certificates). - target URL is invalid. - the `timeout` is exceeded during navigation. - the remote server does not respond or is unreachable. - the main resource failed to load.
will not throw an error when any valid HTTP status code is returned by the remote server, including 404 "Not Found" and 500 "Internal Server Error". The status code for such responses can be retrieved by calling
> **NOTE** either throws an error or returns a main resource response. The only exceptions are navigation to `about:blank` or navigation to the same URL with a different hash, which would succeed and return `null`.

Shortcut for

member.name: M:PuppeteerSharp.Page.WaitForFileChooserAsync(PuppeteerSharp.WaitForFileChooserOptions)
member.summary: Waits for a page to open a file picker
member.remarks: In non-headless Chromium, this method results in the native file picker dialog **not showing up** for the user.
member.example:
This method is typically coupled with an action that triggers file choosing. The following example clicks a button that issues a file chooser, and then responds with `/tmp/myfile.pdf` as if a user has selected this file.
var waitTask = page.WaitForFileChooserAsync(); await Task.WhenAll( waitTask, page.ClickAsync("#upload-file-button")); // some button that triggers file selection
await waitTask.Result.AcceptAsync('/tmp/myfile.pdf');
This must be called *before* the file chooser is launched. It will not return a currently active file chooser.
member.returns: A task that resolves after a page requests a file picker.

member.name: T:PuppeteerSharp.PageAccessibility.Accessibility
member.summary:
The Accessibility class provides methods for inspecting Chromium's accessibility tree. The accessibility tree is used by assistive technology such as screen readers or switches.
Accessibility is a very platform-specific thing. On different platforms, there are different screen readers that might have wildly different output. Blink - Chrome's rendering engine - has a concept of "accessibility tree", which is than translated into different platform-specific APIs. Accessibility namespace gives users access to the Blink Accessibility Tree. Most of the accessibility tree gets filtered out when converting from Blink AX Tree to Platform-specific AX-Tree or by assistive technologies themselves. By default, Puppeteer tries to approximate this filtering, exposing only the "interesting" nodes of the tree.

member.summary: The method launches a browser instance with given arguments. The browser will be closed when the Browser is disposed.
member.returns: A connected browser.
member.remarks:
See this article for a description of the differences between Chromium and Chrome. This article describes some differences for Linux users.
Environment Variables Puppeteer looks for certain environment variables() to aid its operations. - PUPPETEER_CHROMIUM_REVISION - specify a certain version of Chromium you'd like Puppeteer to use. See on how executable path is inferred. **BEWARE**: Puppeteer is only guaranteed to work with the bundled Chromium, use at your own risk. - PUPPETEER_EXECUTABLE_PATH - specify an executable path to be used in . **BEWARE**: Puppeteer is only guaranteed to work with the bundled Chromium, use at your own risk.

member.name: T:PuppeteerSharp.Request
member.summary:
Whenever the page sends a request, the following events are emitted by puppeteer's page: emitted when the request is issued by the page. emitted when/if the response is received for the request. emitted when the response body is downloaded and the request is complete.
If request fails at some point, then instead of event (and possibly instead of event), the event is emitted.
If request gets a 'redirect' response, the request is successfully finished with the event, and a new request is issued to a redirected url.

member.name: P:PuppeteerSharp.Request.RedirectChain
member.summary: A redirectChain is a chain of requests initiated to fetch a resource. If there are no redirects and the request was successful, the chain will be empty. If a server responds with at least a single redirect, then the chain will contain all the requests that were redirected. redirectChain is shared between all the requests of the same chain.

member.name: M:PuppeteerSharp.Request.ContinueAsync(PuppeteerSharp.Payload)
member.summary: Continues request with optional request overrides. To use this, request interception should be enabled with . Exception is immediately thrown if the request interception is not enabled. If the URL is set it won't perform a redirect. The request will be silently forwarded to the new url. For example, the address bar will show the original url.
member.returns: Task

member.summary: Fulfills request with given response. To use this, request interception should be enabled with . Exception is thrown if request interception is not enabled.
member.param: Response that will fulfill this request
member.returns: Task

member.name: T:PuppeteerSharp.States.State
member.summary: Represents state machine for Base process instances. The happy path runs along the following state transitions: -> -> -> -> . -> .

remarks.para:
This state machine implements the following state transitions:
State Event Target State Action ======== =================== ============ ========================================================== Initial --StartAsync------> Starting Start process and wait for endpoint Initial --ExitAsync-------> Exited Cleanup temp user data Initial --KillAsync-------> Exited Cleanup temp user data Initial --Dispose---------> Disposed Cleanup temp user data Starting --StartAsync------> Starting - Starting --ExitAsync-------> Exiting Wait for process exit Starting --KillAsync-------> Killing Kill process Starting --Dispose---------> Disposed Kill process; Cleanup temp user data; throw ObjectDisposedException on outstanding async operations; Starting --endpoint ready--> Started Complete StartAsync successfully; Log process start Starting --process exit----> Exited Complete StartAsync with exception; Cleanup temp user data Started --StartAsync------> Started - Started --EnsureExitAsync-> Exiting Start exit timer; Log process exit Started --KillAsync-------> Killing Kill process; Log process exit Started --Dispose---------> Disposed Kill process; Log process exit; Cleanup temp user data; throw ObjectDisposedException on outstanding async operations; Started --process exit----> Exited Log process exit; Cleanup temp user data Exiting --StartAsync------> Exiting - (StartAsync throws InvalidOperationException) Exiting --ExitAsync-------> Exiting - Exiting --KillAsync-------> Killing Kill process Exiting --Dispose---------> Disposed Kill process; Cleanup temp user data; throw ObjectDisposedException on outstanding async operations; Exiting --exit timeout----> Killing Kill process Exiting --process exit----> Exited Cleanup temp user data; complete outstanding async operations; Killing --StartAsync------> Killing - (StartAsync throws InvalidOperationException) Killing --KillAsync-------> Killing - Killing --Dispose---------> Disposed Cleanup temp user data; throw ObjectDisposedException on outstanding async operations; Killing --process exit----> Exited Cleanup temp user data; complete outstanding async operations; Exited --StartAsync------> Killing - (StartAsync throws InvalidOperationException) Exited --KillAsync-------> Exited - Exited --Dispose---------> Disposed - Disposed --StartAsync------> Disposed - Disposed --KillAsync-------> Disposed - Disposed --Dispose---------> Disposed -
